caption:
I was just looking for a picture of Mortiis for a dumb joke and came across this interview.
I have kids, and I don´t want them to grow up in some sort of dystopian, cynical future. But when people think they can run the world like a company, with no real interest in ramifications and the ripple effects of your actions…Who knows where things will end.
Mortiis has kids?! I keep getting surprised by who has kids these days.
htmlFragment:
• 3/22/2022, 3:47:41 PM

    Mortiis has kids?! I keep getting surprised by who has kids these days.

caption:
- Dropped off.
- Got groceries.
- Did some analysis of home sales last year.
- Researched a couple of more towns' schools. One of them got investigated by the state because they were letting it ride when students harassed others with a confederate flag and yelling "White power".
- Tried to come up with something we could do with my parents on spring break, came up short.
- Did a lot of thinking about real-time vs. turn-based for my game. Did not come up with anything conclusive, but I got farther than I did with the vacation thing.
- Wrote the sample downloading part of my flooding piece.

I was rather ponderous today, it appears.

caption:
From John Maeda’s Laws of Simplicity:
Achieving simplicity in the digital age became a personal mission, and a focus of my research at MIT. There, I straddle the ﬁelds of design, technology, and business as both educator and practitioner. Early in my ruminations I had the simple observation that the letters “M,” “I,” and “T”—the letters by which my university is known—occur in natural sequence in the word SI_M_PLIC_I_T_Y.
Every time I read a book about design, I get this “Um…OK” feeling.
htmlFragment:
• 3/23/2022, 1:25:38 PM
    From John Maeda’s Laws of Simplicity:
    Achieving simplicity in the digital age became a personal mission, and a focus of my research at MIT. There, I straddle the ﬁelds of design, technology, and business as both educator and practitioner. Early in my ruminations I had the simple observation that the letters “M,” “I,” and “T”—the letters by which my university is known—occur in natural sequence in the word SI_M_PLIC_I_T_Y.
    Every time I read a book about design, I get this “Um…OK” feeling.

caption:
Official Orders Books Removed From Schools, Targeting Titles About Transgender People.
“I don’t want a kid picking up a book, whether it’s about homosexuality or heterosexuality, and reading about how to hook up sexually in our libraries,” Glenn said.

He also made it clear that his concerns specifically included books with LGBTQ themes, even if they do not describe sex. Those comments, according to legal experts, raise concerns about possible violations of the First Amendment and federal civil rights laws that protect students from discrimination based on their gender and sexuality.

“And I’m going to take it a step further with you,” he said, according to the recording. “There are two genders. There’s male, and there’s female. And I acknowledge that there are men that think they’re women. And there are women that think they’re men. And again, I don’t have any issues with what people want to believe, but there’s no place for it in our libraries.”
…
The superintendent’s comments reflect a broader national debate. Conservative state legislatures across the country have been considering bills to restrict the ways educators teach about gender and sexuality in schools. This month, the Florida Legislature passed the Parental Rights in Education bill, dubbed the “Don’t Say Gay” bill by its critics, which restricts or bans discussion of LGBTQ issues in the classroom.
There's examples of some brave kids in Texas that are publicly fighting back against this, but not everyone can be brave in that way. A lot of them will be quietly hurt.
htmlFragment:
• 3/23/2022, 3:26:04 PM

    “I don’t want a kid picking up a book, whether it’s about homosexuality or heterosexuality, and reading about how to hook up sexually in our libraries,” Glenn said.

    He also made it clear that his concerns specifically included books with LGBTQ themes, even if they do not describe sex. Those comments, according to legal experts, raise concerns about possible violations of the First Amendment and federal civil rights laws that protect students from discrimination based on their gender and sexuality.

    “And I’m going to take it a step further with you,” he said, according to the recording. “There are two genders. There’s male, and there’s female. And I acknowledge that there are men that think they’re women. And there are women that think they’re men. And again, I don’t have any issues with what people want to believe, but there’s no place for it in our libraries.”
    …
    The superintendent’s comments reflect a broader national debate. Conservative state legislatures across the country have been considering bills to restrict the ways educators teach about gender and sexuality in schools. This month, the Florida Legislature passed the Parental Rights in Education bill, dubbed the “Don’t Say Gay” bill by its critics, which restricts or bans discussion of LGBTQ issues in the classroom.
    There's examples of some brave kids in Texas that are publicly fighting back against this, but not everyone can be brave in that way. A lot of them will be quietly hurt.

caption:
Angry racist roams Roslindale

This made me think of two things:

1) This picks up every time someone who’s not White gets elected to a leadership position.
2) I used to get this kind of thing all the time as a kid. Sometimes every day from certain kids. Knuckledraggers can complain all day about “PC” whatever and critical race theory, but kids that don’t have this kind of bullshit to deal with in “liberal” schools are living the dream.

I wonder if rage about not being allowed to do this in a lot of schools now has driven the 2chan growth. I mean, still worth it, though.
htmlFragment:
• 3/27/2022, 7:43:57 AM
    Angry racist roams Roslindale

    This made me think of two things:

    1) This picks up every time someone who’s not White gets elected to a leadership position.
    2) I used to get this kind of thing all the time as a kid. Sometimes every day from certain kids. Knuckledraggers can complain all day about “PC” whatever and critical race theory, but kids that don’t have this kind of bullshit to deal with in “liberal” schools are living the dream.

    I wonder if rage about not being allowed to do this in a lot of schools now has driven the 2chan growth. I mean, still worth it, though.

caption:
Notable things about the AirBnB we’re staying at that are too picky to put in the official review:

- You can hear the downstairs guy (the owner?) snoring at night.
- You can hear someone else having loud conversations about what so-and-so said on Facebook.
- Upstairs stomping rattles the windows.

Things that might go in the review:

- There’s two allergen containing air fresheners that are really intense.
- There’s a lot of feather pillows and blankets.

The guy was congested, constantly blowing his nose after about a day in. We think it was one of those two things, so we moved them away.
htmlFragment:

caption:
From Game Wizards:
Not that he lacked for other pursuits: “Certain things like my family, religion (JW, you know), work and sex—not necessarily in order of appearance—always find a place sometime during the day. ” For Gygax, all this wargaming was a passion, but not a vocation. Gygax was a conservative Midwesterner, then sporting a neat mustache and sideburns; only rarely did a photograph capture him without a cigarette in hand.
Maybe I’m the prude here, but it seems weird to find frank sexual talk from Gygax, given that it was the ‘70 and he was a Jehovah’s Witness?
htmlFragment:
• 3/27/2022, 8:04:32 PM
    From Game Wizards:
    Not that he lacked for other pursuits: “Certain things like my family, religion (JW, you know), work and sex—not necessarily in order of appearance—always find a place sometime during the day. ” For Gygax, all this wargaming was a passion, but not a vocation. Gygax was a conservative Midwesterner, then sporting a neat mustache and sideburns; only rarely did a photograph capture him without a cigarette in hand.
    Maybe I’m the prude here, but it seems weird to find frank sexual talk from Gygax, given that it was the ‘70 and he was a Jehovah’s Witness?

caption:
We’ve been playing the Mario Golf for the Switch. The guy likes it, and I thought, hey, I’ll play along, but I actually like it, too.

It’s sort of like an extremely fancy Flash game. If you don’t mess with the various clubs, it’s largely a one-dimension game: You hit A when the power meter is at the appropriate spot, and if you do that well, the ball will go close to the target. The way it gets there is satisfying to watch, and it is fun mechanic in the way that the mechanics of improvised physical games are.

It’s sort of an example of the power of “juice”. The game is basically a tiny bit of mechanic and ton of juice triggered by that mechanic. It’s surprisingly different from games that have a lot of cut scenes. In both, there’s a lot of watching in proportion to player acting. But in Mario Golf, the stuff to watch feels like it comes from what the player has done, whereas in the cut-scene-heavy games, the watching feels like it comes from something else.
altText: We’ve been playing the Mario Golf for the Switch. The guy likes it, and I thought, hey, I’ll play al
htmlFragment:

If you don’t mess with the various clubs, it’s largely a one-dimension game: You hit A when the power meter is at the appropriate spot, and if you do that well, the ball will go close to the target. The way it gets there is satisfying to watch, and it is fun mechanic in the way that the mechanics of improvised physical games are.

    It’s sort of an example of the power of “juice”. The game is basically a tiny bit of mechanic and ton of juice triggered by that mechanic. It’s surprisingly different from games that have a lot of cut scenes. In both, there’s a lot of watching in proportion to player acting. But in Mario Golf, the stuff to watch feels like it comes from what the player has done, whereas in the cut-scene-heavy games, the watching feels like it comes from something else.
